headline.main: New Guidelines Advise Less Frequent Pap Smears
headline.print_headline: New Pap Smear Guidelines Advise Less Frequent Tests

docs.abstract: A federal panel and other groups recommend that the Pap test, which screens for cervical cancer and for decades was a yearly ritual for many women, should be done only every third year.
docs.snippet: A federal panel and other groups recommend that the Pap test, which screens for cervical cancer and for decades was a yearly ritual for many women, should be done only every third year.

headline.main: Remember That Study Saying Abortion Makes You Crazy?

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously Tuesday that any rape victim can get an abortion, setting a historic precedent in a country where most abortions are illegal.

headline.main: Argentina: Court Allows Abortion for Rape Victims
headline.print_headline: Argentina: Court Allows Abortion for Rape Victims

docs.abstract: Argentina's Supreme Court unanimously rules that any rape victim can get an abortion, setting a historic precedent in a country where most abortions are illegal.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously Tuesday that any rape victim can get an abortion, setting a historic precedent in a country where most abortions are illegal.

docs.lead_paragraph: A mean-spirited and constitutionally suspect bill called the Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act is both an attack on women’s rights and on the basic principles of federalism.
docs.abstract: Editorial scores the Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act introduced by House Republicans, contending that it is both an attack on women’s rights and on the basic principles of federalism; notes bill would impose a mandatory parental notification requirement and 24-hour waiting period on women under 18 who travel outside their home state to get the procedure.
docs.snippet: A mean-spirited and constitutionally suspect bill called the Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act is both an attack on women’s rights and on the basic principles of federalism.

docs.lead_paragraph: An article in The Lancet suggests that pulling on the umbilical cord, or controlled cord traction, does not significantly reduce blood loss in women and may in fact endanger them.

headline.seo: Study Says Umbilical Cord Shouldn’t Be Pulled During Labor
headline.main: Childbirth: A Different Way to Remove the Placenta May Save Mothers’ Lives, a Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Childbirth: A Different Way to Remove the Placenta May Save Mothers’ Lives, a Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study published in journal The Lancet finds that common midwife practice in Africa and Asia of removing the placenta by pulling on the umbilical cord does not reduce risk of hemorrhage for the mother and carries other unnecessary risks.
docs.snippet: An article in The Lancet suggests that pulling on the umbilical cord, or controlled cord traction, does not significantly reduce blood loss in women and may in fact endanger them.

keywords.value: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
keywords.name: glocations

docs.lead_paragraph: Kara Goucher, 33, will run next week in the New York City half-marathon as she continues her preparations for the Olympic marathon in London.

headline.seo: Kara Goucher’s Route to the Olympics Is Marked by Twists and Turns
headline.print_headline: Route to Olympic Medal Will Have Twists and Turns

docs.abstract: Excerpts from 30 Seconds Q&A with Kara Goucher, one of the United States’ top female distance runners; Goucher will run the marathon for the United States in the 2012 London Olympics.
docs.snippet: Kara Goucher, 33, will run next week in the New York City half-marathon as she continues her preparations for the Olympic marathon in London.

docs.lead_paragraph: Want to know why we can’t get the dog-on-the-roof story straightened out? Just look at the latest happenings in Mittworld.

headline.seo: The Bad News Is Good News
headline.main: The Bad News Is Good News
headline.print_headline: The Bad News Is Good News

docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column criticizes Mitt Romney for supporting the Republican proposal to allow employers to refuse to provide health care coverage for contraception if they have moral objections to birth control; asserts that the good news is that the more the party argues over the issue, the more it loses votes, money and sympathy.
docs.snippet: Want to know why we can’t get the dog-on-the-roof story straightened out? Just look at the latest happenings in Mittworld.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many patients fear tangling with a litigious doctor, or being blackballed by the profession after a negative review of one of its members.

headline.seo: Why the Web Lacks Authoritative Reviews of Doctors
headline.main: The Web Is Awash in Reviews, but Not for Doctors. Here’s Why.
headline.print_headline: The Web Is Awash in Reviews, but Not for Doctors. Here’s Why.

docs.abstract: Ron Lieber Your Money column elaborates on why there is no widespread online system for reviewing physicians, as there are for restaurants, hotels and other services; contends that many patients are reluctant to provide in-depth reviews of their doctors, largely out of fear that the doctor will find out.
docs.snippet: Many patients fear tangling with a litigious doctor, or being blackballed by the profession after a negative review of one of its members.

headline.main: Parental Quandary: Pregnant, With a Job Interview

docs.abstract: Should S. tell a potential employer that she's pregnant?
docs.snippet: Should S. tell a potential employer that she's pregnant?

headline.main: Quandary Considered: Pregnant, When a Friend Is Struggling With Infertility

docs.abstract: Members of the Motherlode community respond to M., who is pregnant and hopes to tell a friend struggling with infertility. Their advice? Be sensitive.
docs.snippet: Members of the Motherlode community respond to M., who is pregnant and hopes to tell a friend struggling with infertility. Their advice? Be sensitive.
